title-group.article-title: Racial/ethnic disparities in timely receipt of buprenorphine among Medicare disability beneficiaries

article-meta.aff: 1Rutgers Institute for Health, Health Care Policy and Aging Research, Rutgers University, New Brunswick, NJ, USA
2School of Social Work, Rutgers University, New Brunswick, NJ, USA
3Department of Medicine, Division of Infectious Diseases, Rutgers New Jersey Medical School, Newark, NJ, USA
4O’Neill School of Public and Environmental Affairs, Indiana University, Bloomington, IN, USA
5National Bureau of Economic Research, Cambridge, MA, USA
6Department of Economics, Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis, Indianapolis, IN, USA
7School of Public Health, Rutgers University, Piscataway, NJ, USA
8Department of Health Behavior, Society and Policy, Rutgers School of Public Health, Piscataway, NJ, USA

fn.p: J. Miles conceived the study, supervised the analyses, and led the writing. H. Samples supervised the study, led the analyses, and assisted with writing. P. Treitler, A. N. Nyaku, and S. Crystal assisted with the analyses, interpretation of findings, and writing. R. Hermida completed the analyses. K. Simon and S. Gupta assisted with interpretation of findings and writing. All authors contributed to the writing and editing of the manuscript; all authors approve of the final version of the manuscript.

author-notes.corresp: Corresponding author: Jennifer Miles, PhD, 112 Paterson Street, Suite 300, New Brunswick, NJ 08901, Tel: 856-520-1622, jm2462@ssw.rutgers.edu

fn.p: Dr. Samples reported receiving consulting fees from the American Society of Addiction Medicine outside the submitted work. Drs. Miles, Treitler, Nyaku, Gupta, Simon, Crystal and Mr. Hermida do not report any conflicts of interest.

sec.title: Background:
sec.p: Medicare disability beneficiaries (MDBs) have disproportionately high risk of opioid use disorder (OUD) and related harms given high rates of comorbidities and high-dose opioid prescribing. Despite this increased risk, little is known about timely receipt of medication for opioid use disorder (MOUD), including potential disparities by patient race/ethnicity or moderation by county-level characteristics.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: National Medicare claims for a sample of MDBs with incident OUD diagnosis between March 2016 and June 2019 were linked with county-level data. Multivariable mixed effects Cox proportional hazards models estimated time (in days) to buprenorphine receipt within 180 days of incident OUD diagnosis. Primary exposures included individual-level race/ethnicity and county-level buprenorphine prescriber availability, percent non-Hispanic white (NHW) residents, and Social Deprivation Index (SDI) score.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: The sample (n=233,079) was predominantly White (72.3%), ≥45 years old (76.3%), and male (54.8%). Black (adjusted hazard ratio [aHR]=0.50; 95% CI, 0.47–0.54), Asian/Pacific Islander (aHR=0.54; 95% CI, 0.41–0.72), Hispanic/Latinx (aHR=0.81; 95% CI, 0.76–0.87), and Other racial/ethnic groups (aHR=0.75; 95% CI, 0.58–0.97) had lower likelihood of timely buprenorphine than non-Hispanic white beneficiaries after adjusting for individual and county-level confounders. Timely buprenorphine receipt was positively associated with county-level buprenorphine prescriber availability (aHR=1.05; 95% CI, 1.04–1.07), percent non-Hispanic white residents (aHR=1.01; 95% CI, 1.00–1.01), and SDI (aHR=1.06; 95% CI, 1.01–1.10).

sec.title: Conclusions:
sec.p: Racial/ethnic disparities highlight the need to improve access to care for underserved groups. Implementing equity-focused quality and performance measures and developing interventions to increase office-based buprenorphine prescribing in predominantly minority counties may reduce disparities in timely access to medication for OUD.
